body: Before its economic turnaround in recent years, Harlem was a case study in disinvestment. title: Wall Street's Tremors Leave Harlem Shaken

title: Far From Hollywood, Red Hook's Grit Sells

title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; On Teasing Walls, Traces of Roasters Past

title: Spare Times

body: EVIDENCE suggests that New Yorkers may be more religiously observant now than three decades ago. The number of churches, temples, mosques and other houses of worship -- many of them in storefronts -- jumped by 37 percent in Manhattan from 1980 to 2000, according to census data. In Brooklyn during the same period, the jump was a whopping 87 percent.
title: POSTING; Brooklyn Churches Come and Go

title: HABITATS | RIDGEWOOD, QUEENS; A 'Farmhouse' Near the L Train

body: The last few re-election races have not been particularly easy ones for Representative Edolphus Towns, a 13-term incumbent from central Brooklyn. title: Brooklyn Congressman and Veteran Of Tough Primaries Faces New Fight

body: Two men were killed in Brooklyn in separate encounters, the police said on Tuesday. In the first, Sanjeev Seekoomar, 34, was found on Tuesday morning stabbed to death in his basement apartment at 326 Carroll Street in Carroll Gardens, the police said. The door to the apartment was pushed in and the apartment ransacked, indicating a possible
title: Killings in 2 Brooklyn Neighborhoods

body: THE restoration of town houses may be one of the most popular hobbies in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, a neighborhood that prides itself on its brownstone blocks. title: LIVING IN | CLINTON HILL, BROOKLYN; Elegance Is Abundant; Groceries Are Less So

body: AS natives of Seattle, where they paid $1,100 for a one-bedroom rental in a downtown neighborhood called Belltown, Brandon and Jette Starniri faced culture shock when they moved to New York three years ago and settled into a Brooklyn Heights walk-up. title: THE HUNT; Taking the Two-Family Path

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites EDIBLE ESTATES Most New Yorkers don't have to worry about lawns; a stoop is luxury enough. body: IF there is a bright spot in New York City's uncertain real estate market, it is that over the last several months, some first-time buyers have found it easier to buy apartments. title: First-Time Jitters

body: A construction worker fell 12 stories to his death in Brooklyn on Wednesday when the scaffold he was standing on collapsed, apparently because of high winds, according to city officials and witnesses. The authorities said the worker, Jose Palacios, 42, of Queens, was one of three men near the roof of the 13-story apartment building at 525 Clinton
title: Scaffold Falls, Killing Worker in Brooklyn

body: AROUND TOWN MARTIN LUTHER KING'S BIRTHDAY The older a holiday is, the more ingrained its traditions. body: As the housing market across the country continued to stagnate in the fourth quarter of last year, the market in Manhattan set a record, according to reports to be released on Thursday by four of the city's major real estate brokerage firms. The average price for an apartment reached $1.4 million in the last quarter of 2007, up 17.6 percent from
title: Apartment Prices in Manhattan Defy National Real Estate Slide
